nodes.text: IoT-based home appliances enable remote management and automation that can make human life easier and more efficient
The Internet of Things is an environment where appliances connect to sensors and the Internet to perform automated operations and enable remote control
IoT-based home automation provides multiple benefits including improved device monitoring, time efficiency, cost savings, quality of life, smart environment control, and health monitoring

IoT technologies and communication protocols relevant to home automation include Bluetooth Low Energy, ZigBee, Z-Wave, WiFi, Cellular (GSM/3G/4G), NFC, and LoRaWAN each with distinct tradeoffs in range, power, data rate, and suitability
This paper uses a literature review of prior prototypes, system designs, and surveys to summarize IoT home automation architectures, applications, technologies, benefits, and challenges
IoT architecture for home automation connects sensors, devices, and networks to enable device-to-device and remote communication
Better monitoring of devices is achieved by IoT through device-to-device transmission reducing need for user intervention and improving operational clarity
IoT-enabled automation increases efficiency and saves user time by avoiding repetitive manual tasks through programmed control
IoT can reduce energy and resource waste, yielding cost savings when devices are monitored and optimized
Integration of AI with IoT can improve comfort, convenience, and overall quality of life through intelligent control and personalization
IoT systems support smart environment functions (e.g., automated window/shade control, pollution monitoring) and health monitoring (e.g., vital sign pattern tracking) for safety and eldercare
Reviewed prototypes and studies report successful WiFi-based and low-cost expandable home automation implementations and demonstrations of remote appliance control
Security, privacy, power consumption, standard fragmentation, and usability for non-IT experts are recurring challenges identified in IoT home automation literature
Limitations and challenges such as security/privacy concerns, power/cost constraints, vendor fragmentation, and user expertise needs must be addressed for wider IoT adoption
